I bought the orange voyager shoes while i was in japan last month. I went into a Vans store to look if they have something rare and guess what i saw. All vans limited space shoes in stock in all sizes. just had to buy them, and they were cheaper too. I looked on the website if they were in stock and nope all sold out.

My wife got a very cool item on our last trip to Kennedy space center, my wife is a quilter and while she's interested in space items I figured that I would enjoy the space shuttle display much more than her. But much to my surprise, one of the employees working there that day was actually one of the women who did the quilting of the outer soft surfaces of the space shuttles, much of what I had always assumes was solid material was actually just highly advanced fabric that a bunch of women (as I recall I think she said there was only a couple men in that job over the life of the program.

So, if your wife us a quilter than you realized i spent far more time exploring the shuttle display than I planned as my wife and this woman, whom I wish I could remember her name, chatted away merrily with my wife and gave her a tour of the outside fabric coverings, explaining how they were put together and what they did, it was actually very interesting. She also showed us a few mostly empty rolls if the various threads they used when sewing the coverings.

Well she gave my wife her business card, and through it she fastened a piece of each of the various threads, some metal, some not, that the woman clipped from the rolls for me wife as a momento. It was, and still is, very cool.

For the more technically-inclined, another great book idea is Ignition!, by John Drury Clark. It's an informal history of the development of liquid rocket propellants, and it really drives home how we ended up with the currently-used propellants -- and why all the other options faded into disuse. Typically, it's because they were insanely dangerous.

I have read Elon Musk biography already, interesting, suggest.

For a telescope, the 50mm celestron is quiiiite limited, specially for the price it brings. With 200$ you can buy a AWB OneSky (outside the US is name Skywatcher Heritage 130P), with 130mm of aperture, you can see much, much more detail in the planets, not to mention the moon, and also the higher aperture means higher light gathering capability, so, seeing deep space nebulaes, galaxies and such in good detail are possible.

I suggest to anyone interested in the topic, to visit /r/telescopes on reddit

Cheers!

Amusingly, I also got hooked on astronomy due to a little 50mm refractor which I bought from a thrift shop for $50, but man, by comparison, that little brass Celestron is really expensive - that's about as much as I paid for my Celestron AstroMaster 130EQ reflector which is a much more capable instrument. Of course, that's when there is something to look at - from mid-november to mid-march the planets will all pass during the day and the sky is predominantly overcast... so no stargazing for me until spring.

Bear in mind, if you want to buy one of Oli Braun's models - he can't provide decals for trademarked logos because he doesn't have a licence for them, so the SpaceX logo will be missing - instead he provides blank decal paper for you to print your own.

Also, I have one of those moon night-lights. it's awesome and I recommend it to everyone.
